title: Voters 'more likely to blame Remainer MPs than Boris Johnson if Brexit is delayed'
text:
brexit countdown_bg Created with Sketch.

Voters are more likely to blame Remain-backing MPs and Parliament than Boris Johnson if Brexit is delayed, according to a new poll.

A survey conducted by ComRes shows that if the UK's departure date is pushed back beyond October 31 then the PM will be at least partially blamed for the extension by just over half of voters.

But crucially for the PM the numbers show that voters will blame other groups far more than they will the premier if he is unable to stick to his 'do or die' Brexit pledge.

The statistics represent a boost for Mr Johnson and Downing Street because they come as the chances of a Brexit deal appear to be shrinking while the possibility of an extension past Halloween increases.

Number 10 is adamant that the UK will leave the EU with or without a deal but the government has also conceded that it will have to comply with the so-called Benn Act.

That anti-No Deal law states that the PM must ask the EU for a delay if the two sides have not struck an accord in the run up to the October 31 deadline.

However, Downing Street has made clear that while it will ask for a delay in such circumstances it will also make plain to the EU that it does not want an extension.

Should a delay be agreed, the ComRes poll for The Telegraph suggests Mr Johnson would have to shoulder some of the blame.

But he is likely to be heartened by the fact other groups would be blamed more than he would.

A survey conducted by ComRes showed 83 per cent of voters would blame Parliament if Brexit is delayed beyond October 31

Respondents were asked the following question: If the UK does not leave the EU on 31st October, to what extent do you think each of the following will be to blame?

On the broad 'to any extent' answer, 56 per cent of people said they would blame Mr Johnson while 44 per cent said they would blame Irish Taoiseach Leo Varadkar.

However, the European Commission, Remain-supporting MPs and Parliament generally all scored worse than the two political leaders.

Some 63 per cent of people said they would blame the European Commission and 70 per cent would blame Remain-backing MPs.

But the most blamed group in such circumstances was Parliament as 83 per cent said the institution would be at least in part at fault if there is a delay.

Some 53 per cent of respondents said Parliament would be to blame for a delay to a 'large extent'.

Mr Johnson would be blamed to a 'large extent' for a Brexit delay by 28 per cent of voters but 33 per cent of voters said Mr Johnson would not be to blame at all.

Just seven per cent of people said Parliament would not be to blame if the UK's departure date is pushed back.

Meanwhile, ComRes also conducted a Westminster voting intention poll which found that the Tories are going forwards while Labour appears to be going backwards.

The latest poll with fieldwork carried out from October 4 to October 6 puts the Conservative Party on 33 per cent, up three points on the last similar poll conducted by the company in September.

The Tories have a six point lead over Labour in the latest ComRes Westminster voting intention poll

Labour is on 27 per cent, down two points on September, giving the Tories a six point overall lead.

Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrats are up two points to 19 per cent, the Brexit Party remained the same on 13 per cent, the Green Party is down one point to three per cent and the SNP is up one point on four per cent.

The poll is likely to spark alarm bells in Labour HQ because it comes after the party and the Tories held their annual conferences.

But while the Tories have extended their lead, Labour appears to be struggling to gain any momentum ahead of a potential snap general election in the winter.
